historySlides.text: Historians believe that golf emerges in Scotland in the early 1400s. For centuries, the game is played on sandy linksland in just a handful of coastal towns, most prominently Edinburgh and St. Andrews. Early golf is principally the domain of the economic and social elite.
historySlides.title: Origins of the Game

historySlides.text: The Industrial Revolution transforms Scottish society, encouraging the rapid growth of golf. There are just 24 golf clubs in Britain in 1851 and at least 290 by 1899. The first generation of golf professionals emerges mid-century and by the 1860s they are competing in elite competitions like the Open Championship.
historySlides.title: Golf & The Industrial Revolution

historySlides.text: Changing perspectives on female sports participation encourage women to take up the game after 1850. The St. Andrews Ladies’ Club forms in 1867 and plays over an area known as the Himalayas. Westward Ho! (1868), Musselburgh (1872) and Carnoustie (1873) quickly follow in creating clubs and courses for women.
historySlides.title: Early Women's Golf

historySlides.text: Golf’s emergence as a global game reflects the breadth of British economic and political interests. Golf spreads to India in 1830 and Australia by 1840. Vacationers and expatriates help extend golf across the Continent, to France in 1856, Belgium in 1888 and Italy and Switzerland by 1890. By 1895, golf proliferates in more than 35 countries.
historySlides.title: Beyond Britain

historySlides.text: Golf is played in America as early as the 1740s, but the game does not flourish in the United States until the 1880s. Many Scottish and English professionals emigrate to America to work at more than 1,000 golf courses that exist by 1900. Some become the first stars of American golf.
historySlides.title: Golf comes to America

eras_by_id.title: The Great <nobr>Golf Boom</nobr>
eras_by_id.description: Golf's first legends emerge as the game's popularity explodes

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Allan Robertson

accomplishments.name: Golf's first professional and greenskeeper
Premier club and ball maker in St. Andrews
First player to break 80 on the Old Course in St. Andrews
Victor in numerous high-profile challenge matches
Frequent partner of Old Tom Morris
Architect of course improvements at St. Andrews and Carnoustie

directus_files_id.description: Undated portrait of Allan Robertson in the collection of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews, ca. 1850
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Allan Robertson

profiles.bioText:
Often identified as the first golf professional in history, Allan Robertson was the first player to earn distinction as the world’s "Champion Golfer." His grandfather and father were celebrated caddies, as well as feathery ball makers and club makers of the highest repute. Allan followed in the family tradition.

Robertson famously competed in numerous high-stakes challenge matches. He took great delight in deliberately extending challenge matches to the 17th hole, when he could have polished off his foe earlier. He did so not only to avoid wounding his opponent’s pride, but also to make it impossible for the opponent to ask for better odds at their next match.
profiles.quote: He is not only the best golf player, but quite a capital ball-maker, and withall a quiet, hard-boned, wired little fellow, always as cool as a cucumber.

directus_files_id.description: Old Tom Morris with workers in front of his workshop on the Links Road in St. Andrews, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Old Tom Morris taken by noted architect and Hall of Fame member A.W. Tillinghast in 1898
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Tribute poem written for Old Tom Morris following his death in 1908
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Oil painting of Old Tom Morris by Sir George Reid, commissioned by members of the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews in 1903
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Old Tom Morris walking through the Cathedral cemetery at St. Andrews to visit the grave of his son, Tommy Morris, ca. 1890
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery7 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Advertisement for Tom Morris golf clubs and golf balls, 1859
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery8 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

accomplishments.description: Morris' victories at the Open Championship included winning the 1862 Open by thirteen strokes, and a victory in 1867 at the age of 46.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the Open Championship
Premier club and ball maker in St. Andrews
Design credits include Carnoustie, Muirfield, Prestwick, and Royal Dornoch
"Keeper of the Green" in St. Andrews from 1865-1904

directus_files_id.description: Old Tom Morris wearing the Championship Belt, awarded to the winner of the Open Championship, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: The earliest known golf photograph, including Old Tom Morris (third from left), taken by Octavius Hill and Robert Adamson, St. Andrews, ca. 1845
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom Old Tom Morris

profiles.bioText:
Forever linked with the Old Course and St. Andrews, four-time Open Champion Tom Morris Sr. is one of the most revered figures in golf. “Old Tom” learned the game as an apprentice of Allan Robertson, caddying for him, making feather balls in Robertson’s shop, and playing with Robertson in many celebrated challenge matches.

Morris served as greenkeeper at Prestwick before returning to St. Andrews in the mid-1860s to manage the links, rebuild the greens and widen the fairways on the Old Course. He is credited as the architect of more than 75 courses throughout the British Isles. He remained a premier player for decades, last playing in The Open Championship in 1896 at age 75.
profiles.quote: One of the most remarkable men—best of men and best of golfers—that ever missed a short putt.

directus_files_id.description: Memorial erected near the grave of Young Tom Morris in the St. Andrews Cathedral cemetery
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Competitors in the Grand Golf Tournament at Leith LInks, 1867, including Young Tom Morris (at top of stairs to right of doorway)
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Young Tom Morris wearing the Open Championship belt by Thomas Rodger, ca. 1870
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Young Tom Morris’ scorecards for the 1870 Open Championship at Prestwick, his third consecutive victory
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

accomplishments.description: Morris first played in, and won, the Open Championship, at age 17.
accomplishments.name: Won four Open Championships by age 21

accomplishments.description: Morris went on to win the Claret Jug with his victory at the 1872 Open Championship
accomplishments.name: Retired the original Open Championship belt in 1870
Recorded the first hole-in-one in a major championship in 1869

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Old and Young Tom Morris by Thomas Rodger, ca. 1870
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

directus_files_id.description: Competitors in the Grand Golf Tournament at Leith Links, 1867, including Young Tom Morris (second from right) and Old Tom Morris (third from right)
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom Young Tom Morris

profiles.bioText:
Tall, strong and handsome, Tom Morris Jr. was to golf in his era what Arnold Palmer became in the 1950s. "Golfers may come and golfers may go," wrote Harold Hutchinson, "but it is very much open to doubt whether any golfers will be quite the idol of the day as Young Tom was during his brilliant career."

He first won a professional challenge match at 13 and a professional tournament at 16. After claiming four Open Championships between 1868 and 1872, tragedy struck in 1875, when Morris received a telegram that his wife and baby had died during childbirth. He died three months later on Christmas Eve of a pulmonary hemorrhage, leading to speculation that he died from a broken heart.
profiles.quote: There isn't a man, English or Scotch, with the same sense of power, or golfing genius as Tommy did, the instant he addressed the ball.

directus_files_id.description: A challenge match at St. Andrews, Allan Robertson and Tom Morris Sr. against Willie Park and Willie Dunn, 1855. Park in center with hands clasped.
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

directus_files_id.description: Photographic portrait of Willie Park Sr., ca. 1880
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

directus_files_id.description: Newspaper clipping recording Willie Park’s victory over Tom Morris Sr. in a three-round challenge match, 1854
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

directus_files_id.description: Portrait of Willie Park Sr, by an unknown artist, possibly executed to commemorate his victory in the 1860 Open Championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

directus_files_id.description: A challenge match at St. Andrews, Allan Robertson and Tom Morris Sr. against Willie Park and Willie Dunn, 1855. Park in center behind players.
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr.

accomplishments.description: Park was victorious at the Open Championship in 1860, 1863, 1866, and 1875. He added four more runner-up finishes in 1861, 1862, 1865, and 1867.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the Open Championship
Designer of at least 35 golf courses in the UK and Ireland

accomplishments.description: Park also famously won a challenge match playing his tee shots from a watch face. The watch was unscathed.
accomplishments.name: Often played challenge matches using only one hand and standing on one leg

directus_files_id.description: Old Willie Park by John A. Bonner, ca. 1880; Park is depicted holding his beloved putter, “Auld Pawky.”
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Sr

profiles.bioText:
Celebrated as a premier club and ball maker from Musselburgh, Scotland, Willie Park Sr. staked his claim to immortality as the inaugural Open Champion in 1860. Like many professionals of his era, Park was introduced to golf as a caddie, using a whittled stick as his first club.

Tall and strong, he soon emerged as one of the most dominant golfers of his generation, gaining notoriety through his victories in challenge matches against contemporaries such as Allan Robertson, Willie Dunn Sr. and Old Tom Morris. He was an excellent putter, but it was his powerful drives that most intimidated his peers. Allan Robertson, who refused to respond to Park's public challenge in 1853, once confessed, "Willie frightens us with his long driving."
profiles.quote: He was not merely good, not merely excellent, but brilliant (as a putter). So deadly was he when within three or four yards of the hole.

directus_files_id.description: Willie Park Jr. prepares to play a shot, ca. 1890
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

directus_files_id.description: Willie Park Jr. putting on the first green of the Old Course, St. Andrews, ca. 1895
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

directus_files_id.description: Advertisement for Willie Park Jr.’s Special Putting Clerk, endorsed by fellow Hall of Fame member Harold Hilton, 1898
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

directus_files_id.description: Scene from the match between Willie Park Jr. and Willie Dunn at the Meadow Brook Club on Long Island, 1896
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

directus_files_id.description: Advertisement for Willie Park Jr., Golf Course Architect, showing the expansion  of his design business to the United States, 1916
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr.

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the Open Championship
Played in his first Open Championship at age 16
Author of the first book by a golf professional
Inventor of the offset putter, lob wedge, and convex-faced driver
Significantly advanced ball aerodynamics
Designed over 150 courses around the world

directus_files_id.description: Willie Park Jr. demonstrates proper putting technique, using his patented offset blade putter, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Willie Park Jr

profiles.bioText:
Willie Park Jr. was golf's first true Renaissance man: two-time Open champion, golf equipment maker, golf writer and one of his era's finest golf course architects. The son of four-time Open Champion Willie Park Sr., and nephew of 1874 Open Champion Mungo Park, Willie Park Jr., was born into the "First Family of Golf." His success was often attributed to exceptional putting, perfected through twelve-hour practice sessions.

Confident, competitive and an iconoclast, Park never sought employment from a club, preferring instead to run his own business. He was an innovator in club and ball design and manufacturing, as well as golf course architecture, and parlayed his fame into business ventures that reached throughout the United Kingdom and extended to America.
profiles.quote: The man who can putt is a match for anyone.

directus_files_id.description: John Ball Jr. competing in the 1912 Amateur Championship at Royal North Devon, where he claimed his last of eight titles
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 the Great Golf Boom John Ball

accomplishments.description: In the process, Ball became the first amateur, and first Englishman, to win the Open Championship.
accomplishments.name: First to with the Open and Amateur Championships in the same year
Eight-time winner of the Amateur Championship
Irish Amateur champion in 1890
Won more than 40 major amateur competitions

directus_files_id.description: John Ball Jr. at the top of his backswing, ca. 1910
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom John Ball

directus_files_id.description: John Ball Jr. driving from the tee, ca. 1910
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom John Ball

profiles.bioText:
A fierce competitor, known for his fiery temper and determined spirit, Englishman John Ball Jr. dominated amateur golf in late nineteenth-century Great Britain, winning eight Amateur Championships between 1888 and 1912, The Open Championship in 1890 and the hearts and respect of his country.

Ball learned the game on the links at Holyoke, competing against his rival and friend, Harold Hilton. His swing was graceful and many contemporaries considered him the most stylish player of his era. But it was his stubbornness and dogged determination that made Ball a lion in match play. He retired with a match-play record of 99 wins against just 22 losses.
profiles.quote: I have derived greater aesthetic and emotional pleasure from watching John Ball than from any other spectacle in the game.

directus_files_id.description: Harold Hilton plays an approach shot, ca. 1910
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

directus_files_id.description: Harold Hilton putting the final match of the 1911 U.S. Amateur against Fred Herreshoff at the Apawamis Club in Rye, New York
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

directus_files_id.description: Harold Hilton and Freddie Tait at the 1896 Amateur Championship at Royal St. George’s Golf Club
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

directus_files_id.description: Harold Hilton (left) and W.H. Hamilton at Royal Portrush, where Hilton claimed his fourth and final Irish Amateur title in 1902
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

accomplishments.name: Two-time winner of the Open Championship
Four-time winner of the Amateur Championship
Two-time winner of the Irish Amateur
Winner of the 1911 U.S. Amateur Championship
First to win the Amateur and U.S. Amateur in the same year
Won over 20 major amateur competitions

directus_files_id.description: Harold Hilton at the 1900 Amateur Championship at St. Andrews, where he claimed his first of four Amateur titles
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

directus_files_id.description: USGA President Silas Strawn presents the champion’s gold medal to Harold Hilton at the 1911 U.S. Amateur championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom Harold Hilton

profiles.bioText:
Harold Hilton, a powerful, if unconventional, shot-maker, won The Open Championship in 1892—the first time it was played at 72 holes and contested over two days—and again in 1897. But it was his dominance of English amateur golf, and his rivalry with John Ball Jr., that earned him widespread fame.

A wild swinger who re-gripped the club at the top of his backswing, Hilton owned a stellar match play record, boasting a 99-29 mark in amateur competitions. After retiring from competitive golf, Hilton authored several books on golf and became the founding editor of **Golf Monthly** and editor of **Golf Illustrated.**
profiles.quote: He was a small man of powerful physique; it was exhilarating to watch his perky walk between shots. His assiduity was his greatness.

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon, watched by Old Tom Morris, on the first tee at St. Andrews, 1905 Open Championship
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon first met 18-year-old Bob Jones during the 1920 U.S. Open at the Inverness Club in Ohio
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon at Pinehurst during his tour of the United States in 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon and legendary English professional Ted Ray at the 1920 U.S. Open at the Inverness Club in Ohio
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

accomplishments.name: Six-time winner of the Open Championship
Winner of the 1900 U.S. Open Championship
Won over 40 professional tournaments
Popularized the overlapping grip

accomplishments.description: The Vardon Trophy is awarded annually by the PGA of America to the PGA TOUR's leader in scoring average.
accomplishments.name: Namesake of the PGA TOUR's Vardon Trophy
Designer of more than 20 courses in the UK and Europe

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon at the top of his backswing, ca. 1910
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon at the Fall River Country Club in Massachusetts during his tour of the United States in 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom Harry Vardon

profiles.bioText:
Harry Vardon possessed a magnetic personality, immense talent and a method so singular that he was considered a shotmaking machine. He was golf’s first international superstar, winning a record six Open Championship titles between 1896 and 1914. He toured the United States in 1900, 1913 and 1920, promoting awareness and driving growth of the game.

Vardon possessed one of the most admired and proficient golf swings the game has ever seen. He stood just 5-foot-9 and tipped the scales at 155 pounds, but he had enormous hands that melted perfectly around the club. His swing was more upright and his ball flight higher than his contemporaries, giving his approach shots the advantage of greater carry and softer landings.
profiles.quote: I cannot believe that anyone ever had or will have a greater genius for hitting a golf ball than Harry Vardon.

directus_files_id.description: J.H. Taylor with his twin daughters Phyllis and Audrey at Royal Mid Surrey Golf Club, ca. 1930
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom Jh Taylor

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery6 the Great Golf Boom Jh Taylor

accomplishments.name: Five-time winner of the Open Championship
Two-time winner of the British PGA Championship
Winner of the French Open, German Open, and Dutch Open
1934 Ryder Cup Captain
Co-founder and first chairman of the British Professional Golfers' Association
Specialized in designing public golf facilities

directus_files_id.description: J.H. Taylor, demonstrating the proper form of the day with a flat backswing, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom Jh Taylor

profiles.bioText:
Legendary Open champions J.H. Taylor, Harry Vardon and James Braid together dominated professional golf from the mid-1890s to the mid-1910s. Taylor earned his spot in this so-called "Great Triumvirate" by winning The Open Championship five times, becoming the first professional from England to do so.

Taylor's ability to play in wind and bad weather set him apart from his peers. He won his last Open Championship in 1913 battling extreme wind and rain, while defeating Ted Ray by eight strokes. Bernard Darwin once characterized him as "a man on wires, having to choke down his temper and often suffering agonies." Beloved by many, he dedicated his later life to writing books, making clubs and designing courses.
profiles.quote: To try to play golf really well is far from being a joke, and lightheartedness of endeavor is a sure sign of eventual failure.

directus_files_id.description: Clement Fowler, The Great Triumvirate, 1912; J.H. Taylor (left), and James Braid (center) watch Harry Vardon (driving)
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

directus_files_id.description: Harry Vardon and James Braid at Murrayfield Golf Club in Edinburgh, Scotland, 1904
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

directus_files_id.description: James Braid driving from the first tee St Andrews, 1905 Open Championship, watched by J.H. Taylor (right) and Old Tom Morris (seated in center)
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

directus_files_id.description: The power of James Braid, ca. 1905
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom James Braid

accomplishments.description: Braid was also runner-up at the Open Championship four times.
accomplishments.name: Five-time winner of the Open Championship
First to break 70 in the Open Championship
Four-time News of the World Match Play champion
Co-founder of the British Professional Golfers' Association
Long-time club professional at Walton Heath

directus_files_id.description: James Braid at the top of his backswing, ca. 1900
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

directus_files_id.description: Open champions, 1929: (rear) Harry Vardon, James Braid, Alec Herd, Jack White, Arnold Massey; (front) George Duncan, Walter Hagen, Jim Barnes, Ted Ray
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 the Great Golf Boom James Braid

profiles.bioText:
A tall, stately man of great character who was a friend of princes, peers and the common man, James Braid was a pioneer in elevating the status of professional golfers. As a golfer, he was a late bloomer, not winning his first Open Championship until Harry Vardon and J.H. Taylor had already won three each. But once Braid won his first in 1901, there was no stopping him. He captured the Open again in 1905, 1906, 1908 and 1910, thus becoming the first man to raise the Claret Jug five times. 

Braid later turned to golf course architecture, designing or redesigning more than 200 courses, including Carnoustie, Royal Troon and the King's and Queen's courses at Gleneagles.
profiles.quote: Keep on hitting it straight until the wee ball goes in the hole.

directus_files_id.description: Willie Anderson, 1904
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

directus_files_id.description: Willie Anderson at the top of his backswing, 1903
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery2 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

directus_files_id.description: Willie Anderson with Alex Smith, the 1906 and 1910 U.S. Open champion
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery3 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

directus_files_id.description: Early U.S. Open champions, including Horace Rawlins (1895, on ground), and Willie Anderson (behind Rawlins) with an arm around Alex Smith (1906, 1910)
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery4 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

directus_files_id.description: Alex Smith, George Low, Willie Anderson and Johnny McDermott, ca. 1910; Smith, Anderson and McDermott each won multiple U.S. Open titles
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery5 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

featuredImage.title: Player Great Golf Boom Willie Anderson

accomplishments.description: Anderson is the only player to win three consecutive U.S. Open titles. He also finished second in 1897, at the age of 17.
accomplishments.name: Four-time winner of the U.S. Open Championship
Four-time winner of the Western Open
Head professional at 10 different clubs

directus_files_id.description: Willie Anderson at the finish of his swing, 1905
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio1 Golfs Golden Age Willie Anderson

profiles.bioText:
Willie Anderson, modest in nature and never boastful of his successes, belongs in the same pantheon of U.S. Open history as Bob Jones, Ben Hogan and Jack Nicklaus. From 1897 to 1910, Anderson won the U. S. Open four times, finished second once, third once, fourth twice and fifth three times. He was, in many respects, the first dominant professional in America.

Reared on the links of North Berwick, Scotland, Anderson was a sturdy man with muscular shoulders, brawny forearms and exceptionally large hands. He played with a flat, full-sweeping action known as the "St. Andrews swing." Despite what many considered to be swing flaws, Anderson was consistently accurate. He died prematurely of arteriosclerosis at age 31.
profiles.quote: Most likely, had he lived longer, Willie would have set a record for U.S. Open championships that would never be beaten.
profiles.quoteByline: Alex Smith, 1906 and 1910 U.S. Open champion

directus_files_id.description: Legendary British golf writer and Hall of Fame member Bernard Darwin (left) with Charles Blair Macdonald at the National Golf Links of America, 1913
directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Gallery1 Golfs Golden Age Charles Blair Macdonald

directus_files_id.title: Player Capstone Bio2 Golfs Golden Age Charles Blair Macdonald

profiles.bioText:
Charles Blair Macdonald, a "founding father" of American golf, was a driving force in the creation of the United States Golf Association in 1894. He was introduced to golf at age 16, when his parents sent him to live with his grandfather in St. Andrews, Scotland. He quickly became skilled enough to play regularly on the Old Course with two of the finest players of the day—Davey Strath and Young Tom Morris.

Several years after Macdonald returned to the United States, he designed a seven-hole course for the 1893 World's Fair in Chicago, launching a career as a world-class architect. No less an authority than Bernard Darwin accurately referred to Macdonald as the first great American golf course architect.
profiles.quote: Putting greens to a golf course are what the face is to a portrait.
